page.title: Flag and coat of arms of Terengganu

revision.comment: Rescued 1 archive link; remove 1 link. [[User:GreenC/WaybackMedic_2.1|Wayback Medic 2.1]]
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=March 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} '''The [[flag]] and the [[coat of arms]] of Terengganu''' are [[federated state|state]] [[symbol]]s of [[Terengganu]], a [[States of Malaysia|state]] in [[Malaysia]]. Like the majority of state symbols for states with Malay royalties, the flag and the arms of Terengganu centre on [[Sultan of Terengganu|its royalty]], as well as [[Islam]], the state's traditional religion.
== Flag ==
=== Design === [[File:Flag of Terengganu.svg|thumb|right|250px|[[File:FIAV 110000.svg|23px|State flag.]] The flag of Terengganu. Flag ratio: 1:2.]]
First revealed in 1953,<ref name="star idris">{{cite web |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2006/10/13/nation/15701374 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521135850/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2006/10/13/nation/15701374 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=21 May 2011 |title=Idris: Terengganu needs vibrant flag |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date=13 October 2006 |publisher=''[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]'' }}</ref> the present flag of Terengganu encompasses a black flag with a thick, white [[Flag terminology#Basic patterns in flags|border]] and a white [[star and crescent]] in the centre that points towards the [[Flag terminology#Description of standard flag parts and terms|fly]].<ref name="fotw">{{cite web |url=http://flagspot.net/flags/my-teren.html |title=Trengganu (Malaysia)|accessdate=24 September 2008 |author=Various authors |date=7 June 2008 |publisher=[[Flags of the World]] }}</ref> The width of the crescent is five-sixths the width of the black panel, while the width of the star, which is tilting clockwise, is two-thirds that of the crescent.<ref name="fotw"/>
The white signifies the [[Sultan of Terengganu]], while the black signifies the state's citizens; with the white border surrounding the black panel, the layout represents the Sultan's duty to protect his subjects.<ref name="terengganu.gov flag">{{cite web |url=http://www.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/portal/cms/ikon/article.php?cid=1&aid=871 |title=Bendera Negeri |language=Malay |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Government website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090708115532/http://www.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/portal/cms/ikon/article.php?cid=1&aid=871 |archivedate=8 July 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The star and crescent denote [[Islam]] as the official religion of the state.<ref name="terengganu.gov flag"/>
In October 2006, then-[[List of Menteris Besar of Terengganu|''Menteri Besar'' of Terengganu]] [[Idris Jusoh]] voiced intentions by the state government to "[brighten] up" the flag and incorporate an emblem by first seeking opinions from professions, citing feedback of the flag being too "simple and dull".<ref name="star idris"/> As of 2008, there have been no reports of further action.
=== Variants ===
==== District flags ==== Terengganu has eight [[Daerah|administrative districts]] (''[[daerah]]''), each assigned their own district-level flags.<ref name="terengganu.gov districts">{{cite web |url=http://www.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/portal/cms/ikon/article.php?cid=1&aid=872 |title=Bendera Daerah |language=Malay |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Government website }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> All eight of the flags consist of only a single coloured [[Flag terminology#Description of standard flag parts and terms|field]] with the state flag on the [[Flag terminology#Description of standard flag parts and terms|canton]]; the only distinction is the colour of the field, which corresponds to respectable districts and represents their qualities:<ref name="terengganu.gov districts"/><ref name="fotw district">{{cite web |url=http://flagspot.net/flags/my-ter-m.html |title=Municipal flags in Terengganu (Malaysia) |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author=Various authors |date=19 July 2008 |publisher=[[Flags of the World]] }}</ref>
{|class="wikitable" |- ! District !! Flag !! Field colour !! Symbolisation |- | [[Besut]] || [[File:Flag of Besut, Terengganu.svg|border|150px]] || [[Red]] || Besut's development of land and power-generating infrastructures. |- | [[Dungun]] || [[File:Flag of Dungun, Terengganu.svg|border|150px]] || [[Cyan]] || Dungun's [[fishing industry]] and [[tourism]] due to the presence of ''Penyu Belimbing'', a species of [[sea turtle]]s, at its beaches. |- | [[Hulu Terengganu]] || [[File:Flag of Hulu Terengganu, Terengganu.svg|border|150px]] || [[Orange (colour)|Orange]] || Hulu Terengganu's courage and willingness to work hard. |- | [[Kemaman]] || [[File:Flag of Kemaman, Terengganu.svg|border|150px]] || [[Blue]] || Kemaman's strength in the development of petroleum and natural gas-related industries. |- | [[Kuala Terengganu]] || [[File:Flag of Kuala Terengganu, Terengganu.svg|border|150px]] || [[Yellow]] || Kuala Terengganu as the capital district of Terengganu, as its state capital and the royal state capital are both situated in the district. |- | [[Marang (district)|Marang]] || [[File:Flag of Marang, Terengganu.svg|border|150px]] || [[Purple]] || Marang's responsibility in restoring of unity among its people. |- | [[Setiu]] || [[File:Flag of Setiu, Terengganu.svg|border|150px]] || [[Brown]] || Setiu's distribution of power by its people for the development of towns and cities. |- | [[Kuala Nerus]] || [[File:Flag of Kuala Nerus, Terengganu.svg|border|150px]] || [[Pink]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Latar Belakang Daerah Kuala Nerus|url=http://pdtknerus.terengganu.gov.my/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=81&Itemid=97|website=Laman Web Rasmi Pejabat Daerah Dan Tanah Kuala Nerus|accessdate=5 November 2016}}</ref> ||Kuala Nerus' knowledge-supported and balanced development for the prosperity of the people. |}
==== Royal Standards ==== Terengganu's royalty, mostly prominently the [[Sultan of Terengganu]], fly their own [[Royal Standard]]s.
[[File:Bendera Sultan Terengganu.jpg|200px|thumb|right|The Royal Standard of the Sultan.]]
The Sultan's Royal Standard is known as ''Tanah Putih'' and consists of a white flag bearing a partial rendition of [[#Coat of arms|the state emblem]], as well as a wreath of [[rice]] stalks and a [[motto]].<ref name="fotw"/><ref name="king standard">{{cite web |url=http://museum.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/agensi/article.php?cid=43&aid=3334 |title=The Body Flag Of His Royal Highness The Sultan Of Terengganu |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Museum website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722234551/http://museum.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/agensi/article.php?cid=43&aid=3334 |archivedate=22 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Previously a plain white flag,<ref name="fotw"/> the additional emblem, which is coloured yellow, was added to identify the flag to Terengganu's royal family.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.istana.terengganu.gov.my/tanah_putih.php |title=Laman Web Rasmi |publisher=Istana.terengganu.gov.my |date= |accessdate=23 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402101010/http://www.istana.terengganu.gov.my/tanah_putih.php |archivedate=2 April 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The design of the ''Pemaisuri''{{'}}s (Queen's) Royal Standard (which is given the name ''Tanah Kuning Tua'') is very similar to that of the Sultan's, but features a reversed arrangement of colours, with a white emblem against a yellow field.<ref name="queen standard">{{cite web |url=http://museum.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/agensi/article.php?cid=43&aid=3335 |title=The Body Flag Of Her Royal Highness The Queen Of Terengganu |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Museum website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722234705/http://museum.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/agensi/article.php?cid=43&aid=3335 |archivedate=22 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.istana.terengganu.gov.my/tanah_tua.php |title=Laman Web Rasmi |publisher=Istana.terengganu.gov.my |date= |accessdate=23 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402143709/http://www.istana.terengganu.gov.my/tanah_tua.php |archivedate=2 April 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Royal Standard of the ''Yang Di-pertuan Muda'' (Crown Prince) bears a similar colour configuration as the Queen's, but features only the partial rendition of the state emblem, which is significantly larger than that of the Sultan's and the Queen's. The Royal Standard for the Crown Prince is named as ''Tanah Kuning Muda''.<ref name="fotw"/><ref name="prince standard">{{cite web |url=http://museum.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/agensi/article.php?cid=43&aid=3336 |title=The Body Flag Of His Highness The Crown Prince Of Terengganu |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Museum website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722234719/http://museum.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/agensi/article.php?cid=43&aid=3336 |archivedate=22 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.istana.terengganu.gov.my/tanah_kuning.php |title=Laman Web Rasmi |publisher=Istana.terengganu.gov.my |date= |accessdate=23 March 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402103738/http://www.istana.terengganu.gov.my/tanah_kuning.php |archivedate=2 April 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==== Obsolete flags ==== Prior to the adoption of the present flag, the state flag of Terengganu previously sported a significantly different design, although many of its elements would be carried over to its successor. The earliest known variant of the state flag was used between 1925 and 1933, and consisted of only a white-black flag divided vertically with the black stripe two times wider than the white stripe.<ref name="fotw"/>
[[File:Flag of Terengganu (1912 - 1933).svg|200px|thumb|left|Flag used until 1933.]]
In 1933, a star and crescent that pointed upwards and featured rounder crescent was added on the black band, signifying Terengganu's recognition of Islam as the state's religion.<ref name="fotw"/> The flag remained in use until the introduction of the current flag.
[[File:Flag of Terengganu (1933 - 1947).svg|200px|thumb|left|Flag used until 1953.]]
Additionally, the state government of Terengganu formerly flew its own "Governmental Service Flag", which design originated in the same manner as the state flag. Bearing the same vertical white-black layout, a white [[saltire]] was also included on the black stripe.<ref name="fotw"/> Similarly, a star and crescent was also added in a later date, but was placed on the white stripe.<ref name="fotw"/> The flag was rendered obsolete following the adoption of the present state flag, which was also to be used by the state government.
==State Emblem==
=== Design === [[File:Coat of arms of Terengganu.svg|thumb|The state emblem of Terengganu.]]
Approved for official use by the State Ministers Committee in 1932, the state arms or emblem (Malay: ''Jata'') of Terengganu was designed by several state officials during the reign of [[Zainal Abidin III|Sultan Zainal Abidin III]] (1881–1918), and is thought to have been drawn by Mohamad bin Abdul Rahim, the relative of Dato' Nara Wangsa (Dato' Mata-Mata).<ref name="fotw"/><ref name="terengganu.gov emblem">{{cite web |url=http://www.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/portal/cms/ikon/article.php?cid=1&aid=653 |title=Jata Kebesaran |language=Malay |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Government website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080907064520/http://www.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/portal/cms/ikon/article.php?cid=1&aid=653 |archivedate=7 September 2008 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
The arms originally consisted of a white outlined oval that encompassed a series of symbols coloured in yellow and a [[Jawi script|Jawi]] [[motto]].<ref name="fotw"/><ref name="terengganu.gov emblem"/> During the rule of [[Ismail Nasiruddin of Terengganu|Sultan Ismail Nasiruddin Shah]] (1945–1979), the emblem was modified with the addition of a dotted figure of a [[Seal (device)|seal]] around all of the symbols except the [[star and crescent]], which resides over the seal, the addition of a pair of maces and the shortening of the motto.<ref name="fotw"/><ref name="terengganu.gov emblem"/>
Details of the emblem's components are as follows:<ref name="fotw"/><ref name="terengganu.gov emblem"/>
;Star and crescent :The [[star and crescent]] reside atop the seal, pointing upwards. As a symbol of the [[Islam|Islamic faith]], they represent Terengganu as an Islamic state.
;Seal :The seal consists of a near-oval, shield-like dotted outline that encompasses virtually all symbols in the emblem with the exception of the star and crescent, including: :* A [[crown (heraldry)|crown]], located near the top, which represents the sovereignty of the [[Sultan of Terengganu]]; :* a [[sword]], a long ''[[kris]]'' and a pair of [[ceremonial mace]]s (The sword and ''kris'' crisscrosses each other to the top, while the maces crisscrosses each other lower down), which symbolise the royal paraphernalia of Terengganu;<ref name="royal regalia">{{cite web |url=http://museum.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/agensi/article.php?cid=43&aid=3326 |title=ROYAL PARAPHERNALIA |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Museum website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722234726/http://museum.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/agensi/article.php?cid=43&aid=3326 |archivedate=22 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> :* two books, located on opposing sides of the seal below the upper half of a mace and the lower half of the sword or ''kris'', represent two important books in Terengganu: The Book of Law—placed on the left—denoting justice and the [[Qur'an]]—placed on the right—denoting the Law; and :* a [[scarf]] (''wali'' or ''selampai''), which wraps around the sword or ''kris'' and over the maces, signify a portion of the state's cultural regalia.<ref name="royal regalia"/>
;Motto The [[motto]], "Terengganu" written in [[Jawi script|Jawi]] (ترڠڬانو), is located below the seal. When introduced in 1932, the emblem's motto originally read "''Jawatan Kerajaan Terengganu''" (Terengganu Government Post) in Jawi.<ref name="terengganu.gov emblem"/> During the rule of [[Sultan Ismail Nasiruddin Shah]], "''Jawatan Kerajaan''" was omitted from the motto, resulting in its present form.<ref name="terengganu.gov emblem"/>
=== Royal Standard variants === The state emblem of Terengganu is included on the [[#Royal Standards|Royal Standards of Terengganu's royal family]], but differs slightly, as it is only duplicated partially, without the outlining oval border and seal, the "Terengganu" [[motto]] and the star and crescent. Two elements are added on the emblem in the case of the Royal Standards for the Sultan and the Queen: a [[wreath]] of [[rice]] stalks and a different motto depicted in the form of banner to be written in [[Jawi script|Jawi]].<ref name="king standard"/><ref name="queen standard"/> The motto corresponds to the individual the Standard is assigned to; as such, the motto for the Standard of the Sultan reads "''Sultan Terengganu''" while that of the Queen reads "''Pemaisuri Terengganu''".<ref name="king standard"/><ref name="queen standard"/> The emblem on the Royal Standard of the Crown Prince consists of only the partial replication of the state emblem.<ref name="prince standard"/>
As the Standard of the Sultan has a white field, the emblem retains its yellow colour.<ref name="king standard"/> However, as the Standard of the Queen and the Crown Prince bare yellow fields, their emblems are white.<ref name="queen standard"/><ref name="prince standard"/>
== References == {{reflist}} <!--|Ref reserved in event refs in main body is deleted for some reason. <ref name="fotw">{{cite web |url=http://flagspot.net/flags/my-teren.html |title=Trengganu (Malaysia) |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author=Various authors |date=7 June 2008 |publisher=[[Flags of the World]] }}</ref>
<ref name="fotw district">{{cite web |url=http://flagspot.net/flags/my-ter-m.html |title=Municipal flags in Terengganu (Malaysia) |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author=Various authors |date=19 July 2008 |publisher=[[Flags of the World]] }}</ref>
<ref name="terengganu.gov flag">{{cite web |url=http://www.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/portal/cms/ikon/article.php?cid=1&aid=871 |title=Bendera Negeri {{ms icon}} |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Government website }}</ref>
<ref name="terengganu.gov emblem">{{cite web |url=http://www.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/portal/cms/ikon/article.php?cid=1&aid=653 |title=Jata Kebesaran {{ms icon}} |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Government website }}</ref>
<ref name="terengganu.gov districts">{{cite web |url=http://www.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/portal/cms/ikon/article.php?cid=1&aid=872 |title=Bendera Daerah {{ms icon}} |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Government website }}</ref>
<ref name="king standard">{{cite web |url=http://museum.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/agensi/article.php?cid=43&aid=3334 |title=THE BODY FLAG OF HIS ROYAL HIGHNESS THE SULTAN OF TERENGGANU |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Museum website }}</ref>
<ref name="queen standard">{{cite web |url=http://museum.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/agensi/article.php?cid=43&aid=3335 |title=THE BODY FLAG OF HER ROYAL HIGHNESS THE QUEEN OF TERENGGANU |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Museum website }}</ref>
<ref name="prince standard">{{cite web |url=http://museum.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/agensi/article.php?cid=43&aid=3336 |title=THE BODY FLAG OF HIS HIGHNESS THE CROWN PRINCE OF TERENGGANU |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Museum website }}</ref>
<ref name="royal regalia">{{cite web |url=http://museum.terengganu.gov.my/maxc2020/agensi/article.php?cid=43&aid=3326 |title=ROYAL PARAPHERNALIA |accessdate=24 September 2008 |author= |date= |publisher=Official Terengganu State Museum website }}</ref> --> {{Terengganu}} {{Malaysian flags}} {{Heraldry in Malaysia}}

revision.comment: /* Postwar career */replaced: Post war → Postwar using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=January 2012}}
'''Friedrich Wilhelm Schulz''', alias '''Fritz W. Schulz''', (2 April 1884, in [[Berlin]] – 12 June 1962, in [[Hamburg]]) was a [[Germany|German]] [[marine artist]] and [[illustrator]] of the 20th century. [[File:Fwschulz Portrait 1.jpg|thumb|Fritz W. Schulz in seinem Atelier 1955]]
==Life and work== ===Education=== In 1907, at age 23, Friedrich Wilhelm Schulz, entered the 'Berlin academy for the arts', [[Charlottenburg]]. His teachers were Max Schäfer, M. L. Körte, Hanke, [[Paul Friedrich Meyerheim]] and [[Carl Saltzmann]]. He also studied in Paris with [[Théophile Steinlen]].
===World War I=== In 1909, Schulz was appointed Second [[Lieutenant]] in the [[German Army (German Empire)|German Army]] reserve and was stationed with the 24th [[Infantry]] Regiment, in [[Neuruppin]]. Sent directly to hostilities in 1914, Schulz was wounded and spent the remainder of [[World War I]] in the air services as an airman, hangar officer and Captain.
===Family=== In 1914, Schulz married Martha Elise Maria Kühn (24 February 1888, Neuruppin - 10 December 1966, [[Hamburg]]). They had two daughters; Ilse Agnes Piper, née Schulz (15 August 1915 - 13 September 2006, [[Hamburg]]) and Käthe Luise Schulze-Wenck, née Schulz (16 December 1916 - 30 September 2010, [[Itzstedt]]).
===The Berlin studios=== Schulz lived in Berlin and had several studios there; at Holsteiner Ufer, in the Wilsnackerstrasse and lastly in the Kantstrasse. He painted under his pseudonym, "Fritz W. Schulz" and marked his paintings with his initials 'F.S.W'. At the height of his career, Schulz rarely took part in art exhibitions and refused to join the NSDAP.{{clarify|date=April 2012}}
===World War II=== In 1945, in the [[Second World War]], when [[Berlin]] was bombed, Schulz and his family moved to Neuruppin and from there to [[Apenrade]], [[Denmark]]. From 6 June 1945 till 24 October 1948, Schulz and his family lived in the refugee camp at [[Oxböl]], Denmark, where Schulz devoted his time to the promotion of the arts and to cultural education. During this time he drew maps for school lessons and worked as a teacher in the camp. In 1948, the family was admitted to the French zone of Germany and lived in an apartment in [[Aldingen]]. On 7 March 1949, Schulz was relieved from the jurisdiction III, Az. 16/KW/2091.{{clarify|date=April 2012}}
===Postwar career=== Schulz moved to [[Stuttgart]], Germany in 1951 and in 1955 to Hamburg where he joined the [[Sezession]]. His works can be found in the 'Museum of Marine Science' in Berlin.
== Journeys == * 1925 – with the German fleet on the liner ''Elsass'' to Norway * 1931 – to [[Galveston]], Texas
==Estate== Schulz's estate is managed by his three grandsons, Joachim, Hellmut and Jürgen Schulze-Wenck.
==Selected works== * ''SMS-Emden'' at the Museum of Oceanography, Berlin. * ''Niobe'' at the Museum of Oceanography, Berlin. * 1933: "Franz Klasen" for the Deutsch-Amerikanische Petroleum Gesellschaft (DAPG) in Berlin. * 1933: "C.A. Mowinckel" for DAPG, Paris. * 1933: "Andromeda" for director Herzer, DAPG, Berlin. * 1933: "Andromeda" - drawing for DAPG, Hamburg. * 1942: "Herren des Atlantik" exhibited and awarded in "Das Meer".
== References == * ''Velhagen & Klasings Monatshefte'' January 1937; publisher Velhagen & Klasing; page 540 and page 567 ff. * ''Maler in Hamburg – 1966-1974'', Volker Detlef Heydorn 3; publisher Christians Hamburg 1974; page 141. * ''Deutsche Marinemalerei'', Hans Jürgen Hansen; publisher Stalling 1977; page 50 ff.
== External links == {{Commonscat}} * [http://www.Fritz-W-Schulz.de www.Fritz-W-Schulz.de]
== Gallery == <gallery> File:Fwschulz 001Schiff.jpg|Dreimaster auf See File:Fwschulz 057Schiff.jpg|Auf der Neufundlandbank File:Fwschulz 097Schiff.jpg|Sturmwind File:Fwschulz 102Meer.jpg|Tosende See File:Fwschulz 009Schiff.jpg|Schiffe im Nebel </gallery>
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Schulz, Fritz W.}} [[Category:Marine artists]] [[Category:20th-century German painters]] [[Category:German male painters]] [[Category:German illustrators]] [[Category:1884 births]] [[Category:1962 deaths]] [[Category:Artists from Berlin]]

page.title: Gabrielle d'Estrées et une de ses sœurs

revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Scuola di fontainebleau, presunti ritratti di gabrielle d'estrées sua sorella la duchessa di villars, 1594 ca. 06.jpg | title=Portrait présumé de Gabrielle d'Estrées et de sa soeur la duchesse de Villars | artist=Unknown author | year= circa 1594 | type=oil on wood | height_metric=96 | width_metric=125 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum= Louvre }}
'''''Gabrielle d'Estrées et une de ses soeurs''''' (''Gabrielle d'Estrées and one of her sisters'') is a painting by an unknown artist circa 1594. It now hangs at the [[Musée du Louvre|Louvre]] in Paris and is usually thought to be the work of a painter from the [[Fontainebleau School]].<ref>{{Citation|title=Gabrielle d'Estrées and one of her sisters |publisher=mheu |year=2009 |url=http://www.mheu.org/en/timeline/8/gabrielle-estrees.htm |accessdate=17 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219012427/http://www.mheu.org/en/timeline/8/gabrielle-estrees.htm |archivedate=19 December 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref name="epic_arts">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PWEQAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA151&dq=Gabrielle+d%27Estr%C3%A9es+and+one+of+her+sisters&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEYQ6AEwB2oVChMIzuSn576PxgIVw3-SCh14gwBL#v=onepage&q=Gabrielle%20d'Estr%C3%A9es%20and%20one%20of%20her%20sisters&f=false | title=Epic Arts in Renaissance France | publisher=OUP Oxford | author=Usher, Phillip John | year=2014 | pages=151 | isbn=9780199687848 | quote=In the School of Fontainebleau painting, ''Portrait présumé de Gabrielle d'Estrées et de sa sœur la duchesse de Villars'' (Presumed Portrait of Gabrielle d'Estrées and of her Sister the Duchess of Villars)…}}</ref>
==Description==
The painting portrays [[Gabrielle d'Estrées]], mistress of King [[Henry IV of France]], sitting nude in a bath, holding a ring. Her sister sits nude beside her and pinches d'Estrées' right nipple.<ref name=Hagen>{{cite book|last=Hagen|first=Rose-Marie|title=What Great Paintings Say, Volume 2|year=2002|publisher=Taschen|location=Köln|isbn=9783822813720|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OWe3lPyY_GIC|author2=Rainer Hagen|page=205}}</ref>
==Interpretations==
===Announcing Gabrielle's pregnancy=== The nipple-pinching gesture is often interpreted as a symbolic announcement that Gabrielle is pregnant with Henry's child, [[César de Bourbon, duc de Vendôme|César de Bourbon]]. According to the Louvre's website: "The oddly affectionate way in which the sister is pinching Gabrielle d'Estrées' right breast has often been taken as symbolizing the latter's pregnancy with the illegitimate child of Henry IV. This interpretation would seem to be confirmed by the scene of the young woman sewing - perhaps preparing a [[layette]] for the coming child - in the background."<ref>[http://www.louvre.fr/llv/oeuvres/detail_notice.jsp?CONTENT%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673225164&CURRENT_LLV_NOTICE%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673225164&FOLDER%3C%3Efolder_id=9852723696500815&bmLocale=en# Official site of the Louvre Museum - Portrait présumé de Gabrielle d'Estrées et de sa soeur la duchesse de Villars] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427202251/http://www.louvre.fr/llv/oeuvres/detail_notice.jsp?CONTENT%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673225164&CURRENT_LLV_NOTICE%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673225164&FOLDER%3C%3Efolder_id=9852723696500815&bmLocale=en |date=2009-04-27 }}</ref> The ring that Gabrielle holds is said to be Henry's coronation ring, which he supposedly gave to her as a token of his love shortly before she died.
===Erotic interpretations=== In the early years of the seventeenth century, [[Pierre de Bourdeille, seigneur de Brantôme]] tells a story about a group of women who went to view the painting. He claims that the painting shows "fair naked ladies" together in a bath, and adds that they "touch, and feel, and handle, and stroke, one the other, and intertwine and fondle with each other." Brantôme reveals that while the group of women were viewing the painting, "one great lady" who was a part of the group "los[t] all restraint...before the picture, say[ing] to her lover, turning toward him [as if] maddened [by] the madness of love she beheld [in the painting]: 'Too long have we tarried here. Let us now straightway take [my] coach and go to my lodging; for...no more can I hold in the ardor that is in me. Needs must away and quench it; too sore do I burn.'"<ref>[https://people.ok.ubc.ca/parthur/loughlin/Veaudry.doc# ''Selections from Pierre de Bourdeilles, Seigneur de Brantôme, Lives of Gallant Ladies: A Critical Introduction and Annotated Edition'', trans. by Jessica Veaudry.]</ref>
In the first half of the nineteenth century, ''Gabrielle d'Estrées et une de ses soeurs'' was hanging in the Prefecture of Police in Paris. Dr. Ver Heyden de Lacey states in an article from 1935 that "Nobody knew why or how it came there; [it was] placed above a door in one of the halls to which the public had access."<ref>"A Picture of Gabrielle d'Estrées attributed to François Pourbus le Jeune," ''Connoisseur'', Vol. 96 (1935): 137-8.</ref> He explains that one day, a "pusillanimous high official" noticed the painting and "conceived [of] the idea to screen the picture...from the curious public gaze, by drawing a green curtain in front of it." This action suggests that the official considered the painting to be erotic or even obscene, but instead of removing it, he had it veiled, and he thus visibly marked the image as an open secret, or as something which should not be seen. At some point after that, Dr. Ver Heyden de Lacey claims that "Somebody had the happy inspiration to expose [the veiled image] to the artistic and art-trained eyes of those called upon to take part in [a] civic function [at the police station]...In preparation [for this] special function...a thorough cleaning of the picture itself was ordered...[But] Upon drawing the curtain, [they found only] an empty picture frame."
In the twentieth and twenty-first centuries, the ''Gabrielle d'Estrées'' painting is regularly understood to represent female homosexuality. There is an entry for it in the ''Encyclopedia of Lesbian Gay Histories and Cultures'' and it appears on websites about lesbian history like Sappho.com.<ref>''Encyclopedia of Lesbian and Gay Histories and Cultures'', eds. George Haggerty and Bonnie Zimmerman. NY: Garland. {{ISBN|9780815333548}}.</ref> Even outside of the [[LGBT]] community, the painting is frequently understood as a representation of lesbianism. In 1991, it appeared on the cover of the French magazine ''L’Événement du jeudi'' to illustrate a story on lesbian chic.<ref>''L’Événement du jeudi'' Number 361, 3–9 October 1991.</ref> In 2002, the Green Party in Germany created a poster to announce their support of same-sex marriage and it featured two female actors reenacting the ''Gabrielle'' portrait.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.spiegel.de/fotostrecke/skurrile-wahlwerbung-fotostrecke-107962-25.html |title=Skurrile Wahlwerbung: Sex, Lügen und Wahlplakate |trans-title=Absurd Political Advertising: Sex, Lies and Election Posters |date=15 January 2009 |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |accessdate=24 October 2018 }}</ref>
===Bias toward left-handedness=== This painting is peculiarly biased toward left-handedness. Gabrielle's sister is pinching her right nipple with her left hand, d'Estrées is holding the ring with her left hand, and the seamstress in the background is sewing with her left hand. Additionally, the painting hanging in the background is of the lower body of a naked person, but contrary to rumor, he is not holding his penis with his left hand; a piece of red fabric is draped over his genitals.
==In popular culture==
A sprightly British drama, ''[[Two Nudes Bathing]]'', speculates upon the origins of the anonymous painting.
An anachronistic visual reference to the painting appears in ''[[The Tudors]]'', Season 1, Episode 6 "True Love".
==References== ===Footnotes=== {{reflist}} ===Sources=== * [http://www.lehman.edu/academics/arts-humanities/english/documents/TextualPracticeArticle.pdf# Will Fisher. "Gabrielle's New Clothes: Cultural Valuations and Evaluations of ''Gabrielle d'Estrées et une de ses soeurs''." ''Textual Practice'' 12:3 (1998): 251-67.] * Rebecca Zorach. "Desiring Things." ''Art History'' 24.2 (2001): 195-212.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gabrielle d'Estrees et une de ses soeurs}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Hestia-meyers.png|thumb|right|The ''Giustiniani Hestia'' in [[Oskar Seyffert (classical scholar)|O. Seyffert]], ''Dictionary of Classical Antiquities'', 1894]] [[File:Hestia Giustiniani.jpg|thumb|left|Hestia Giustiniani]] The '''Giustiniani Hestia''' is a finely-executed marble [[sculpture]], a perhaps [[Hadrian]]ic Roman copy of a Greek bronze of about 470 BCE, now in the [[Torlonia Collection]] (see [[Torlonia Museum]]), Rome, but named for its early owner, marchese [[Vincenzo Giustiniani]]. It is the only known Early Classical bronze that was reproduced at full size in marble for a Roman collection: Roman taste ran more towards the [[Hellenistic]] baroque.
==Description== [[Johann Joachim Winckelmann|Winckelmann]] cited the ''Hestia Giustiniani'' as an example of the austere early stage of [[Ancient Greek sculpture|Classical Greek sculpture]]. For female figures, early fifth-century sculptors mostly gave up the crinkly sleeved ''[[Chiton (costume)|chiton]]'', which had been popular in the later sixth century BCE, and returned to the sleeveless ''[[peplos]]'' with heavy, dominantly vertical folds not unlike the fluting of a column.<ref>Compare the contemporaneous ''[[Charioteer of Delphi]]''.</ref> With the body so shrouded the relaxation of pose has been limited to turning the head. Several Attic or Argive sculptors have been speculatively suggested as the author of the lost original.
==History== The sculpture was known in the [[Giustiniani]] collection in [[Palazzo Giustiniani, Rome|Palazzo Giustiniani]], Rome, from the early 1630s, the date of a drawing made for the antiquarian [[Cassiano dal Pozzo]]<ref>Now in the archival volumes of his "paper museum" conserved in the Royal collection at [[Windsor Castle]], vol. ix, folio 29 (Lachenal).</ref> and was illustrated in the engraved catalogue of the Galleria Giustiniani, produced under the direction of [[Joachim von Sandrart]] in two deluxe volumes, 1635–36 and 1638<ref>The ''Hestia'' appears in vol. I, plate XVII (1635-36).</ref> In its first appearance in a Giustiniani inventory, 1638, it was a ''"vergine vestale vestita, di marmo greco tutta antica alta palmi 9"'' (quoted by Lachenal), "a clothed [[Vestal Virgin]], of Greek marble wholly antique, height 9 palmi." The sculpture appeared in [[François Perrier (painter)|François Perrier]], ''Segmenta nobilium signorum'' (Paris and Rome, 1638), plate lxxii. The ''Hestia'' was purchased from the Giustiniani heirs in the nineteenth century and re-erected in Palazzo Lungara, where it was described by [[Ennio Quirino Visconti]]. It was removed to the Torlonia [[Villa Albani]] after World War II and was reinstalled in the 1990s in the courtyard of the Palazzo Torlonia in [[via della Conciliazione]].
==Identification== Contemporary scholars are less certain about the sculpture's identification as Hestia, in part because of literary references to her imageless sanctuaries,<ref>Jean-Joseph Goux, "Vesta, or the Place of Being", ''Representations'' '''1''' (February 1983), pp. 91-107.</ref> though a similar figure is painted on a cup at Berlin attributed to the Sosias Painter (Lachenal): [[Demeter]] and [[Hera]] are alternative candidates. Often such attribution issues are skirted in modern scholarship by designating such sculptures simply as ''peplophoroi'' ("peplum-wearers")
==Notes== <!--This article uses the Cite.php citation mechanism. If you would like more information on how to add references to this article, please see http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Cite/Cite.php --> {{refbegin}} {{refend}} {{reflist}}
==References== *[http://www.suffragio.it/suffragio/cultura/Hestia.htm Lucilla de Lachenal, ''Hestia Giustiniani"] (Italian) *[http://www.classics.cam.ac.uk/museum/guideearlyclass.html (Museum of Classical Archaeology, University of Cambridge) Guide to the Cast Gallery: Early Classical Style)]: the Giustiniani Hestia among casts that represent the Greek canon for the British nioneteenth century. *[http://www.theoi.com/Gallery/S13.1.html Giustiniani Hestia illustrated]
[[Category:Roman copies of 5th-century BC Greek sculptures|Giustiniani Hestia (Roman copy)]] [[Category:Sculptures of goddesses]]

{{Infobox Occupation | image= [[File:Shamir Brothers.jpg|250px]] | caption= Graphic Designers [[Gabriel and Maxim Shamir]] | official_names= [[Creative director]], [[art director]] <!------------Details-------------------> | type= [[Profession]] | activity_sector= [[Advertising]], [[book design]], [[brand management|branding]], [[illustration]], [[page layout]], [[typography]], [[webcomic]], [[web design]] | competencies= Technical knowledge, cultural relevance, art history | formation= | employment_field= | related_occupation= [[Production artist]], [[graphic artist]], [[website designer]], [[desktop publishing]] | average_salary= }}
A '''graphic designer''' is a professional within the [[graphic design]] and [[graphic arts]] industry who assembles together images, [[typography]], or motion graphics to create a piece of design. A graphic designer creates the graphics primarily for [[published media|published]], [[print media|printed]] or [[electronic media]], such as [[brochure]]s (sometimes) and [[advertising]]. They are also sometimes responsible for [[typesetting]], [[illustration]], user interfaces, and [[web design]]. A core responsibility of the designer's job is to present information in a way that is both accessible and memorable.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.aiga.org/content.cfm/what-is-design | title = What is graphic design? | author = Jessica Helfand | publisher = ''[[AIGA]]'' | accessdate = 2009-06-29 | quote = it is the art of visualizing ideas }}</ref>
== Qualifications== A Bachelor's degree or certificate from an accredited trade school is usually considered essential for a graphic design position. After a career history has been established, though, the graphic designer's experience and number of years in the business are considered the primary qualifications. A [[Career portfolio|portfolio]], which is the primary method for demonstrating these qualifications, is usually required to be shown at job interviews, and is constantly developed throughout a designer's career.
One can obtain an [[Associate's degree|AAS]], [[Bachelor's degree#BA, AB, BDes, BS, BSc, SB, ScB, BAAS,|BA]], [[Bachelor of Fine Arts|BFA]], BCA, [[Master's degree|MFA]] or an [[Master of Philosophy|MPhil]] / [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] in graphic design. Degree programs available vary depending upon the institution, although typical U.S. graphic design jobs may require at least some form of degree.
Current graphic designer jobs demand proficiency in one or more graphic design software programs. A common software package used in the graphic design industry is [[Adobe Creative Cloud]]. This software package contains the three main programs used by graphic designers, which are Photoshop, Illustrator and InDesign. Photoshop, InDesign, and Illustrator are the industry standard applications for many graphic design positions. Another example of a common software package is [[CorelDraw Graphics Suite]].
Outside the graphic design industry, many people use [[Microsoft Word]] or [[Microsoft Publisher]] to create a layout or design. However, depending on the job at hand, most designers create the layout in either InDesign, CorelDRAW or QuarkXPress. Specifically, the designer will type or import the text in the layout program, also importing the graphics and images they created in Photoshop or Illustrator. There are a couple of reasons a designer builds a layout in this fashion:
*Files going to press are generally printed at 300 dots per inch. As a result, the file size can become very large, depending upon the photos and graphics used in it. By using a layout program and linking these graphics and images (but not saving all of them in the file itself), the working file is a fraction of the file size. When the designer is ready to go to press, s/he will either create a press-ready PDF; or use the "Package" function in InDesign, or the "Collect For Output" function in QuarkXpress or CorelDRAW (which gathers the layout document, plus all fonts and images used therein, and saves them in one folder which can be provided to a commercial printing company for final output). *InDesign, CorelDRAW, or QuarkXPress make it possible to work with large multiple page layouts, such as catalogs and booklets. *Since InDesign, CorelDRAW, and QuarkXPress the original file, linking to the graphics and images, the designer can change the "original file" and it will update all instances throughout the document to save time.
A web designer should understand how to work with [[XML]], [[HTML]], and basic web programming [[Javascript|scripts]]. A print designer should understand the processes involved in printing (including, notably, [[offset printing]]) to be able to produce press-ready artwork.
Designers should be able to solve visual communication problems or challenges. In doing so, the designer must identify the communications issue, gather and analyze information related to the issue, and generate potential approaches aimed at solving the problem. Iterative [[Prototype|prototyping]] and [[user testing]] can be used to determine the success or failure of a visual solution. Approaches to a communications problem are developed in the context of an audience and a media channel. Graphic designers must understand the social and [[Norm (sociology)|cultural norms]] of that audience in order to develop visual solutions that are perceived as relevant, understandable and effective.<ref name="nasad">{{cite web|url=http://www.docstoc.com/docs/110496132/NASAD-Competencies-Summary-Degree-The-BFA-in-Graphic|title=NASAD Competencies Summary|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
Graphic designers should also have a thorough understanding of production and rendering methods. Some of the technologies and methods of production are drawing, offset printing, photography, and time-based and interactive media (film, video, computer multimedia). Frequently, designers are also called upon to manage color in different media.<ref name="nasad"/>
==Career portfolio== 50 years ago, the graphic designer's [[Career portfolio|portfolio]] was usually a black book or large binder in which samples of the artist's best printed pieces were carried to show prospective clients or employers. Printed pieces are often protected inside by being mounted on boards or slipped into Acetate sleeves.
Since the 1990s, portfolios have become increasingly computer digitized and now may be entirely digitized and available on the Internet, or on [[CD]], [[DVD]], or via [[email]].
==Branding== Graphic design relates heavily to [[corporate identity]], the [[brand management|branding]], and "persona" of a corporation. Branding originated in the late 1890s and not only did it emerge as corporate identity, but it also signified corporate quality. Many might recognize the process of "branding" a hot iron symbol or logo onto an animal's body to differentiate other cattle. Branding your business or any other type of asset that requires an identity does help one to be recognized in a commercialized industry. Exceptional graphic designers can easily create a brand that fits the company as well as define it through one simple logo.
==See also== *[[Graphic design occupations]] *[[List of graphic designers]] *[[Mood board]]
== References == {{Commons category|Graphic designers}} {{Reflist}}
<!--Please DO NOT link to specific graphic designers or design agencies, that could be considered advertising.-->
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{italictitle}}[[File:Heures Ch d'Angoulême Saint Georges XVe.jpg|thumb|53v: [[Saint George and the Dragon]] (I. M.), f.53v (1475–1500)]] The '''''Heures de Charles d'Angoulême''''' is a [[book of hours]] commissioned in the late 15th century by [[Charles, Count of Angoulême]], father of king [[Francis I of France]]. It is now in the [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]] in Paris, under the number Latin 1173. The book contains full-page miniatures mostly painted by [[Robinet Testard]], many of which have been adapted from, and inspired by, engravings, including sixteen prints by [[Israhel van Meckenem]] which have been glued onto the vellum and overpainted. The book is notable for both the quality of its art, and its various methods of incorporating prints, which testifies to the "complex history of interchanges between printed materials and manuscript illumination during the later fifteenth century".Matthews, pp.4–6 == Description == [[File:Letter R from folio52r.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.9|One of the [[historiated initial|inhabited letter]]s from the manuscript's unusual Ave Maria (folio 52r)]] A [[book of hours]] is a manuscript designed for personal devotion and was popular in the Middle Ages. This illuminated work made for [[Charles, Count of Angoulême]] by the painter [[Robinet Testard]] is an unusual volume and is more comprehensive than just a set of devotions. The artist seems to understand his sponsor's character. As well as its devotional purpose, the book seems designed to entertain, to arouse curiosity (f. 52v), to amuse (ff 3r, 4v and 5r), to satisfy the sponsor's aesthetic sense (ff. 16v and 26v), to encourage his pastoral feelings (f. 20v), to encourage his chivalrous instincts (f. 2v) and even to flatter him (f. 41v).{{cite web |url=http://docs.moleiro.com/fr_LHCA_LHEVIII_LHEIV_III_16.pdf |title=Les Heures de Charles d'Angoulême |author= |date= |work=Catalogue |publisher=M. Moleiro |accessdate=2 February 2017}} The folios most concerned with personal devotion, the [[Passion of Jesus|Passion]], [[Crucifixion of Jesus|Death]] and [[Resurrection of Jesus|Resurrection of Christ]] (f. 106v), were in fact the work of the engraver [[Israhel van Meckenem]], subsequently coloured by Testard with his characteristic luminous hues. Other work by painters such as [[Jean Bourdichon]] were included and may demonstrate Testard's honesty, his admittance that his talents were insufficient for the task. He also introduced some profane elements such as sexual encounters (ff. 4v and 20v), mythology (f. 41v) and chivalry (f. 53v). The text is entirely in [[Latin]], and the book can be interpreted as being the antithesis of a book of hours, or even an anti-book of hours. Some important pages include; the animated scene of the [[Annunciation to the shepherds]]; the mysterious image showing the death of the [[centaur]]; the moral scene "Combat between Virtue and Vice"; the political scene "Death of [[Louis XI of France|Louis XI]]"; the picture of "the Spider King and his daughter Madame [[Anne de Beaujeu]]"; and [[George of Cappadocia]], a legendary scene which is more appropriate to a [[chivalric romance]] than a book of hours. {{Multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = | header_background = | footer = An example of the use of prints in the book of hours.
Testard has borrowed the composition for his ''Judgment of Solomon'' from Netherlandish printmaker [[Master FVB]]'s c. 1480 engraving. He has made several slight alterations: the appearances of the faces and costumes in some of the crowd, minor architectural details, and a slightly lower viewpoint. | footer_align = | footer_background = | width = | image1 = Judgment_of_Solomon_Master_FVB.jpg | width1 = 170 | caption1 = Master FVB's engraving | alt1 = | image2 =LHCA13.jpg | width2 = 145 | caption2 = Testard's painting}} == Manuscript == The manuscript is composed of 230 folios. It includes 38 full-page [[Miniature (illuminated manuscript)|miniatures]]. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:80%;" |+ Selection of miniatures |- ! scope=col | Folios ! scope=col | Description ! scope=col | Miniature |- |1r-6v |[[Liturgical year|Liturgical Calendar]] |[[File:LHCA2.jpg|120px]] |- |7v |[[Christ Pantocrator]] and the [[Tetramorph]] This miniature is adapted by Testard from an engraving by van Meckenem, itself a copy of an [[:File:Maître E. S. Saint Jean Baptiste et l'agneau de Dieu L. 149.jpg|earlier 1466 print]] by [[Master E. S.]] The original print features John the Baptist in the centre, whom Testard has replaced with Christ amongst angels. Surrounding, the four symbols of the evangelists are arranged in a [[Latin cross]]: John's eagle (top), the winged lion of Mark (left), the bull of Luke (right), and Matthew's angel (bottom). The other medallions show the four doctors of the Church: [[Jerome]] with lion (top left); [[Pope Gregory I|Gregory]] (top right), [[Augustine]] (bottom right), and Ambrose (bottom left). Testard largely keeps to original composition, which may have been a design for a [[paten]]. He has made some alterations to the faces and postures of the other characters, and added four prophets to the corners, skillfully extending and elaborating the foliate motifs to unify the image.[http://www.moleiro.com/en/books-of-hours/the-hours-of-charles-of-angoulme/miniatura/516c1f3a66be7 Lepape]Matthews, p.15 |[[File:LHCA3.jpg|120px]] |- |9v |[[Annunciation]] |[[File:LHCA4.jpg|120px]] |- |16v |Floral composition with birds |[[File:LHCA5.jpg|120px]] |- |17v |[[Pentecost]] |[[File:LHCA6.jpg|120px]] |- |18v |[[Nativity of Jesus]] An overpainting of a van Meckenem engraving, itself a reversed version of a c. 1480 print by [[Martin Schongauer]]. The ground and sky have been extended through use of additional overpainted strips.Matthews, p.15 |[[File:LHCA7.jpg|120px]] |- |20v |[[Annunciation to the shepherds]]: country dance A scene of a country dance which at first seems unconnected to this part of the book of hours. Closer examination reveals it to be a combination of religious and picturesque elements: a shepherd in the background points to an angel in the sky who is accompanied by a [[Speech scroll|phylactery]] bearing the words of the [[Gloria in excelsis Deo]].[http://www.moleiro.com/en/books-of-hours/the-hours-of-charles-of-angoulme/miniatura/516c1f990f7dd Hermant] |[[File:LHCA8.jpg|120px]] |- |22v |[[Adoration of the Magi]] (J. B.) |[[File:LHCA9.jpg|120px]] |- |24v |[[Presentation of Jesus at the Temple]] |[[File:LHCA10.jpg|120px]] |- |26v |Floral composition |[[File:LHCA11.jpg|120px]] |- |28v |Prayer to Our Lady |[[File:LHCA12.jpg|120px]] |- |34v |[[Judgment of Solomon]] The composition of this scene is based upon a print by [[Master FVB]]. Testard has altered the faces, costumes and amount of characters, introduced a lower viewpoint and made minor modifications to architectural details.Matthews, p.9-10 |[[File:LHCA13.jpg|120px]] |- |41v |Death and the Centaur Testard has been influenced here by Netherlandish printmaker [[Master I. A. M. of Zwolle]]'s ''Battle of Two Men with a Centaur'', to which he introduces [[Death (personification)|Death]], a lion and a [[Wild man|wild-woman]].Matthews, p.10 Interpretation of this scene is problematic. Typically understood to represent a [[Centaur]] battling the [[Lapiths]], a purely mythological tale and unusual subject for use in the "Office for the Dead", Belkin posits that this contest between man and beast is "symbolic of the struggle against dark forces. The Centaur and the wild woman form a single unit—the personification of vice in terms of Christian allegory. The private nature of the Book of Hours leads one to infer that Charles used the allegory of the struggle with the Vices for his own political vendetta against his rivals, conveying in this enigmatic miniature his bitter enmity towards those who had wronged him."Belkin, p.31 |[[File:LHCA14.jpg|120px]] |- |52r |[[Hail Mary|Ave Maria]] 17 [[Historiated initial|historiated letters]] on a background of gold which spell "Ave Maria, gracia ple[na]" from the first chapter of Luke. This is the reading for the [[Feast of the Annunciation]] (March 25) The first letter is copied from the alphabet of [[Master E. S.]] (itself inspired by the late-14th century pattern-book by {{illm|Giovannino de' Grassi|it}}). Testard seems to have modeled the rest of the letters upon another woodblock alphabet of around 1464 from Flanders or the Netherlands.[http://www.moleiro.com/en/books-of-hours/the-hours-of-charles-of-angoulme/miniatura/5640868159100 Lepape] Two incomplete prints of the 1464 alphabet series are in the British Museum, [http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=1349441&partId=1 B,10.1–23] and 1947,0724.1–19. |[[File:Illuminated_human_alphabet.jpg|120px]] |- |52v |Diagram for calculating the date of Easter On the reverse of the Ave Maria is a diagram for [[Computus|calculating the date of Easter]]. Originally, "the vivid colours of the concentric circles behind the diagram must have stood out more clearly against the cream-coloured parchment [however] one of the components used to make the golden ground of the Ave Maria, probably silver, has gone rusty and seeped deep into the parchment". The main spoke, pointing up, features a sequence of nineteen Roman numerals representing years in the [[Metonic cycle]].[http://www.moleiro.com/en/books-of-hours/the-hours-of-charles-of-angoulme/miniatura/56408458d0169 Hermant] |[[File:LHCA16.jpg|120px]] |- |53v |[[Saint George and the Dragon]] (I. M.) A print by van Meckenem, lightly coloured by Testard, depicting St George, patron saint of chivalry and military orders across medieval Europe. "The choice of this dragon-slaying saint rather than [[St Michael]], the patron saint of the crown of France from Louis XI onwards, was probably the result of a desire to disassociate Charles from the king of France". Testard leaves the original print largely unaltered except for the conical hat and veil of the princess which he has replaced with a turban reflecting contemporary fashion.[http://www.moleiro.com/en/books-of-hours/the-hours-of-charles-of-angoulme/miniatura/56408477a4322 Lepape] |[[File:LHCA.jpg|120px]] |- |59v |[[Last Supper]] and prayer in the garden (I. M.) |[[File:LHCA17.jpg|120px]] |- |74v |[[Arrest of Jesus]] (I. M.) |[[File:LHCA18.jpg|120px]] |- |77v |[[Sanhedrin trial of Jesus]] (I. M.) |[[File:LHCA17.jpg|120px]] |- |80v |[[Flagellation of Christ]] (I. M.) |[[File:LHCA20.jpg|120px]] |- |87v |[[Crown of thorns]] (I. M.) |[[File:LHCA21.jpg|120px]] |- |89v |[[Ecce homo]] (I. M.) |[[File:LHCA22.jpg|120px]] |- |91v |[[Pontius Pilate]] washes his hands (I. M.) |[[File:LHCA23.jpg|120px]] |- |94v |[[Stations of the Cross]] (I. M.) |[[File:LHCA24.jpg|120px]] |- |97v |[[Crucifixion of Jesus]] (I. M.) |[[File:LHCA25.jpg|120px]] |- |106v |[[Burial of Jesus]] (I. M.) |[[File:LHCA26.jpg|120px]] |- |110v |[[Resurrection of Jesus]] (I. M.) |[[File:LHCA27.jpg|120px]] |- |113v |[[Emmaus]] (I. M.) |[[File:LHCA28.jpg|120px]] |} == See also == * [[Charles, Count of Angoulême]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} == Bibliography == * {{Cite news|language=en|first1=Anne|last1=Matthews|title=The use of prints in the Hours of Charles d'Angoulême|journal=[[Print Quarterly]]|volume=3|issue=1|year=1986|pages=4–18|jstor=41823707}} * ''Les Heures de Charles d’Angoulême'' (facsimile of the manuscript), [[M. Moleiro Editor]], 230 p. [http://www.moleiro.com/fr/livres-d-heures/les-heures-de-charles-dangoulme.html Read online] * {{cite journal|title="La Mort du Centaure". A propos de la miniature 41v du "Livre d'Heures" de Charles d'Angoulême |journal= Artibus et Historiae|volume= 11|issue=21|year=1990|pages=31–38|first=Ahuva|last=Belkin|doi=10.2307/1483382|jstor=1483382}} == External links == {{Commons category|Heures de Charles d'Angoulême – BNF Lat1173}} * [http://archivesetmanuscrits.bnf.fr/ead.html?id=FRBNFEAD000059106 BNF catalog] * [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b8432895r Reproduction intégrale du manuscrit] on Gallica * [http://mediatheque-numerique.inp.fr/Videos-cycle-patrimoine-ecrit/Les-Heures-de-Charles-d-Angouleme Présentation du manuscrit] on the site of the {{ill|Institut national du patrimoine (France)|fr|3=Institut national du patrimoine (France)|lt=Institut national du patrimoine}} * [http://www.histoires-de-paris.fr/livre-heures-charles-angouleme/ ''Le livre d’heures de Charles d’Angoulême''] on Histoire de Paris.fr * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9zk1YMuBSIA ''Les Heures de Charles d'Angoulême : enluminure et gravure à la fin du Moyen-âge''] on YouTube * [http://www.histoirepassion.eu/?1466-Un-Livre-d-Heures-de-Charles-d-Angouleme-Charles-d-Orleans 1466 – ''Un Livre d’Heures de Charles d’Angoulême (Charles d’Orléans)''] on Histoire Passion (26 January 2016) {{DEFAULTSORT:Heures de Charles d'Angouleme}} [[Category:Illuminated books of hours|Charles d'Angouleme]] [[Category:15th-century illuminated manuscripts]] [[Category:Iconography of illuminated manuscripts]] [[Category:Miniature painting]] [[Category:French books]] [[Category:Printmaking]] [[Category:Bibliothèque nationale de France collections]]

revision.comment: Undid revision 869562998 by [[Special:Contributions/49.206.211.197|49.206.211.197]] ([[User talk:49.206.211.197|talk]]) Unexplained edit
revision.text:
[[File:Ibn Arabi Books.png|thumb|Mediaeval list of Ibn Arabi's books]]
'''The Seal of the Saints''' or '''"Khatam ul Awliya"''' is a central concept in the writings of 12th-century [[Islamic]] thinker and spiritual leader [[Ibn Arabi]].
== Concept of ''The Seal of the Saints'' in Ibn Arabi's writings ==
Ibn Arabi (1165-1240), in his ''"[[Mecca]]n Revelation"'' (''"Futuhati Maqiyya"''),<ref name="Meccan1">{{cite book | title=Meccan Revelations 1 | publisher=Pir Press |author1=Al Arabi, Ibn |author2=Chodkiewicz, Michel |author3=Morris, James W. | year=2002 | isbn=978-1-879708-16-7}}</ref> explains that all the prophets and saints derive their light from the spirit of [[Muhammad]], the [[Islamic prophet|prophet of Islam]].<ref>{{cite book | title=Seal of the Saints: Prophethood and Sainthood in the Doctrine of Ibn 'Arabi | publisher=Fons Vitae | author=Chodkiewicz, Michel | isbn=0-946621-40-3}}</ref>
In Ibn Arabi's thinking, the prophets and saints are manifestations of the spirit of Muhammad, which is the start and end point of the whole spiritual hierarchy. The first manifestation of the spirit of Muhammad was the first man, [[Adam]]. The last and most perfect was Muhammad himself.
=== Two lines of spiritual transmission ===
In the [[Mysticism|mystical]] branch of Islam, [[Sufism]], there are two main lines of spiritual transmission:
# The 40 [[tariqa]]s, which trace their line of Spiritual Transmission through Ali Ibn abi Thalib to the prophet Muhammad. The Seal of Saints of the 40 Tariqas line is said to be Ibn Arabi himself.<ref>Toshihiko Izutsu. ''Sufism and Taoism'', page 270</ref> # The chain of transmission which runs through Abu Bakr us Siddique to Muhammad. The Seal of Saints of the Abu Bakr as Siddique line is Abdullah Faiz Dagistani. This is the [[Naqshbandi]] (or Siddiqi) Tariqa.<ref name=Nazim>[http://www.sheiknazim2.com/khatmulawliya.html Khatm ul Awliya (The Seal of Saints), Sheikh Abdullah Faiz Daghistan] Retrieved 15 October 2011</ref>
Ibn Arabi, in his book ''"The Astonishing Phoenix – on the Seal of the Saints and the Sun of the West"'', explains that the name of the Seal of Saints is Abdullah, who is a despised [[ajami]].<ref name=Nazim /> Ibn Arabi describes the Seal of Saints in detail, using notably difficult symbolic language.
Similarly, Sharafuddin ad Dagistani, Moulana Sheikh Nazim and Adnan Kabbani explain that the Seal of Saints of the Siddiqi or Naqshbandi Tariqa is Abdullah Faiz Dagistani.<ref name=Nazim />
== Bibliography == * Michel Chodkiewicz (author). Liadain Sherrard (translator). ''The Seal of the Saints. Prophethood and Sainthood in the Doctrine of Ibn 'Arabi''. The Islamic Texts Society. 1993. * Gerald T. Elmore. ''Islamic Sainthood in the Fullness of Time: Ibn al-'Arabi's Book of the Fabulous Gryphon''. Koninklijke Brill, The Netherlands, 1998. {{ISBN|90-04-10991-9}} (Chapter VI. The Seal of the Saints.) [https://books.google.com/books?id=mD5ogBK5eS8C&pg=PA131&dq=%22Seal+of+the+saints%22&hl=en&ei=6IrCTvz-KJPe8QPSnoC0BA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Seal%20of%20the%20saints%22&f=false Google books] * A. E. Affifi. ''The Mystical Philosophy of Muhyid Din-ibnul Arabi''. Cambridge University Press, 1939. [https://books.google.com/books?id=GRA9AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA99&dq=%22Seal+of+the+saints%22&hl=en&ei=6IrCTvz-KJPe8QPSnoC0BA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Seal%20of%20the%20saints%22&f=false Google books] * Toshihiko Izutsu ''Sufism and Taoism: a comparative study of key philosophical concepts''. University of California Press, 1984 [https://books.google.com/books?id=GPT9uAypnOEC&pg=PA270&dq=%22Seal+of+the+saints%22&hl=en&ei=6IrCTvz-KJPe8QPSnoC0BA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22Seal%20of%20the%20saints%22&f=false Google books]
==See also== *[[List of Sufis influenced by Ibn 'Arabī]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.sheiknazim2.com/khatmulawliya.html The Seal of Saints: Abu Bakr us Siddique line: Sheikh Abdullah Faiz Daghistani ] * [http://www.besharapublications.org.uk/pages/wisdom2.html Extracts from ''The Wisdom of the Prophets'' by Ibn Arabi] * [http://www.dar-sirr.com/Tijanism/khatmiya.html Dar-Sirr] "The Sparkled Bridegroom in the Concealness and Sealness of Abil Abbas Tijani the Phoenix" * [http://www.ibnarabisociety.org/articles/anqamughrib.html Ibn al-'Arabī's ''Book of the Fabulous Gryphon'' ('Anqā' Mughrib)] * [http://www.ibnarabisociety.org/reviews/r1008.html Review of Chodkiewicz's ''Seal of the Saints'' by James Morris]

revision.text:
[[File:Dürer-Hieronymus-im-Gehäus.jpg|thumb|''[[Saint Jerome in His Study (Dürer)|St. Jerome in His Study]]'', engraving by [[Albrecht Dürer]], 1514.]] The '''Kupferstich-Kabinett''' (English: '''Collection of Prints, Drawings and Photographs''') is part of the [[Staatliche Kunstsammlungen Dresden|Staatliche Kunstsammlungen]] (State Art Collections) of [[Dresden]], [[Germany]]. Since 2004 it has been located in [[Dresden Castle]].<ref name=dus>[http://www.dresden-und-sachsen.de/dresden/ks_kupferstichkabinett.htm Kupferstich-Kabinett] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720084737/http://www.dresden-und-sachsen.de/dresden/ks_kupferstichkabinett.htm |date=2011-07-20 }} Information and history from the Dresden and Saxony tourist website. {{de icon}}</ref>
==History==
Like many of Dresden's notable collections, this [[print room]] traces its origins to the [[Electorate of Saxony|Prince-electors of Saxony]]. The art chamber of the [[House of Wettin]], established around 1560, became an independent museum of prints and drawings in 1720.<ref name=dus /><ref name=melzer>[http://www.riha-journal.org/articles/2010/melzer-vorgeschichte-dresdner-kupferstich-kabinett Zur Vorgeschichte des Dresdner Kupferstich-Kabinetts zwischen 1560 und 1738] Christian Melzer, ''Journal of the International Association of Research Institutes in the History of Art'', '''0004'''. 21 June 2010. Retrieved 8 September 2010. {{de icon}}</ref> The collection was expanded in the following centuries. It now describes itself as the oldest museum of graphic arts in the German-speaking world.
Because most items had been evacuated to [[Schloss Weesenstein]] in the early stages of [[World War II]], the collection was saved from the [[Bombing of Dresden in World War II|bombing of Dresden]] in February 1945.<ref name=skd>{{cite web |url= http://www.skd.museum/en/museums-institutions/residenzschloss/kupferstich-kabinett/history-of-the-collection/|title= History of the Collection|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= |website= |publisher= Staatliche Kunstsammlung Dresden|access-date= 6 September 2015|quote=}}</ref> War-time losses were still high; around 50,000 items are still missing.<ref name=skd/> Most of the exhibits were [[Looted_art#Looting_by_the_Soviet_Union|looted]] by the [[Soviet Union]] after the war and did not return to Dresden until the late 1950s,<ref name=dus /> and some when they were put back on display in the [[Albertinum]].
==Collection== [[File:Jan van Eyck - Portrait of Cardinal Niccolò Albergati - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|''[[Study for Cardinal Niccolò Albergati]]'', attributed to [[Jan van Eyck]], c. 1431]] The collection includes over 500,000 items, only a fraction of which can be exhibited. The most renowned artists in the collection include [[Lucas Cranach the Elder]], [[Albrecht Dürer]], [[Jan van Eyck]], [[Francisco de Goya]], [[Hans Holbein the Younger]], [[Michelangelo]], [[Rembrandt]], and [[Rubens]]. There is also a large number of works by artists with strong connections to Dresden, such as [[Caspar David Friedrich]], [[Ludwig Richter]], [[Georg Baselitz]] and [[Johannes Heisig]]. The collection of [[Käthe Kollwitz]] was started in 1898 and now numbers over 200 works from her oeuvre of drawings and graphics.<ref name=dus />
Besides the permanent exhibition, the Kupferstichkabinett also hosts regular special exhibitions featuring both its own works and those on loan from other notable museums.
==See also== [[List of museums in Saxony]]
==Notes and references== <references/> ==External links== * [https://kupferstich-kabinett.skd.museum/en/ Kupferstichkabinett Homepage] of the [[Dresden State Art Collections]]
{{Commons category|Kupferstich-Kabinett (Dresden)|Kupferstichkabinett, Dresden}}
{{coord|51|03|10|N|13|44|13|E|region:DE-SN_type:landmark_source:kolossus-dewiki|display=title}}

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=La_lecture.jpg | image_size= | title= La Lecture | artist= [[Pablo Picasso]] | year= 1932 | medium= Oil on panel | height_metric= 65.5 | width_metric= 51 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | museum= Private collection }} '''''La Lecture''''' (or '''''Reading'''''<ref name="Reuters">{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/20/us-finearts-picasso-idUKTRE70I61520110120|title=Painting of muse by lovestruck Picasso up for auction |last=Buffery|first=Vicky|date=20 January 2011|work=[[Reuters]]|publisher=[[Thomson Reuters]]|accessdate=1 February 2011<!--|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wAt38OeV|archivedate=1 February 2011 -->}}</ref>) is a painting by Spanish artist [[Pablo Picasso]] completed in January 1932. The [[oil painting]] depicts Picasso's mistress and muse, [[Marie-Thérèse Walter]], asleep with a book upon her lap. The painting led to the breakup of Picasso's marriage to [[Olga Khokhlova]] after she saw it at a retrospective exhibition and realised that the facial features were not her own. The painting went to auction in 1989 and in 1996, where it failed to sell. In January 2011, it was announced that ''La Lecture'' would be going to auction on 8 February. The painting, which had not been seen in Europe since the exhibition, was then displayed at [[Sotheby's]] in Paris.
==Background== Picasso met [[Marie-Thérèse Walter]] in 1927 as she exited the Paris Metro and they later began a relationship, which they kept secret because she was only seventeen and Picasso was married to [[Olga Khokhlova]].<ref name="Reuters"/><ref name="BBC">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-12333330|title=Picasso painting La Lecture up for auction|date=1 February 2011|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=1 February 2011 <!--|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wAuRXEGg|archivedate=1 February 2011-->}}</ref> Until he painted ''La Lecture'', Picasso often embedded some of Walter's features in the backgrounds of his other works.<ref name="BBC"/> When ''La Lecture'' was exhibited at a Picasso retrospective, Khokhlova realised that her husband was in a relationship with another woman after noticing that the facial features in the painting were not hers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/nri/art-culture/Picassos-portrait-of-his-mistress-to-fetch-millions/articleshow/7403518.cms|title=Picasso's portrait of his mistress to fetch millions|date=1 February 2011|work=[[The Times of India]]|publisher=[[The Times Group]]|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> She ended her marriage to Picasso shortly afterward.<ref name="BBC"/> Walter later inspired other Picasso works including ''[[Le Rêve (Picasso)|Le Rêve]]'', which Picasso painted in the same month as ''La Lecture'', and ''[[Nude, Green Leaves and Bust]]''.<ref name="Reuters"/><ref name="BBC"/> On Walter's influence on Picasso and his work, ''The Art Wolf'' said "Marie-Thérès's potent mix of physical attractiveness and sexual naivety had an intoxicating effect on Picasso, and his rapturous desire for her brought about a number of images that are among the most sought after of his long career."<ref name="ArtWolf">{{cite web|url=http://www.theartwolf.com/news/picasso-lecture-en.htm|title='La Lecture', a Picasso portrait of his muse Marie-Thérèse, to be auctioned in London|date=18 January 2011|publisher=The Art Wolf|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
==Description== Picasso painted ''La Lecture'' from December 1931 to its completion in January 1932 during, what art experts have named, his "lovestruck period."<ref name="Reuters"/><ref name="EuroNews">{{cite news|url=http://www.euronews.net/2011/01/20/erotic-picasso-work-tops-sotheby-auction/|title=Erotic Picasso work tops Sotheby's auction|publisher=[[Euronews]]|date=20 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> The painting is oil on panel and is 65.5 by 51 centimeters.<ref name="ChinaC">{{cite news|url=http://english.cntv.cn/program/cultureexpress/20110121/103450.shtml|title=Picasso's "La Lecture" to be sold in Pairs|date=21 January 2011|publisher=[[China Central Television]]|accessdate=1 February 2011<!--|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wBG9LxJq|archivedate=1 February 2011 -->}}</ref> Picasso has used bright colours, including yellow and green, to depict a nude Walter asleep in a chair with a book in her lap.<ref name="Reuters"/><ref name="Guardian">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/jan/17/picasso-sothebys-la-lecture-auction|title=Picasso to make biggest impression at Sotheby's sale|last=Brown|first=Mark|date=17 January 2011|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|accessdate=1 February 2011<!--|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wAw4FHLR|archivedate=1 February 2011-->}}</ref> Mark Brown of ''[[The Guardian]]'' said the book in Walter's lap is a "sexual symbol" and the painting has been described as being sensual, erotic and happy.<ref name="EuroNews"/><ref name="Guardian"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704754304576095693496901786?mod=googlenews_wsj|title=Making a Big Impression|last=Studer|first=Margaret|date=28 January 2011|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|publisher=[[Dow Jones & Company]]|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Of the painting and Picasso, Philip Hook from Sotheby's said "In the early 1930s he was very lyrically in love and reflected that in these gorgeous colors, and lovely compositions. This period is just about the most desirable of all Picasso's (periods), certainly in market terms."<ref name="Reuters"/> As Picasso painted ''La Lecture'' just days apart from ''La Rêve'', the two paintings are very similar in composition.<ref name="ArtWolf"/>
==Auctions== The painting was auctioned in 1989 and it sold for [[United States dollar|$]]5.8 million.<ref name="LongFaces">{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/long-faces-at-ny-art-houses-1345237.html|title=Long faces at NY art houses|last=Helmore|first=Edward|date=2 May 1996|work=[[The Independent]]|publisher=Independent Print Limited|accessdate=1 February 2011<!--|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wB97KYUt|archivedate=1 February 2011 -->}}</ref> In 1996, ''La Lecture'' went to auction again at [[Christie's]] in New York. It was estimated to sell between $6–8 million, but it failed to sell after bidding stopped at $4.8 million.<ref name="LongFaces"/><ref name="Bloomberg">{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-18/picasso-s-sleeping-mistress-may-fetch-28-6-million-at-sotheby-s-in-london.html|title=Picasso's Sleeping Mistress May Fetch $28.6 Million at Auction|last=Reyburn|first=Scott|date=18 January 2011|publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|accessdate=1 February 2011<!--|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wB82C95R|archivedate=1 February 2011-->}}</ref> ''[[The Independent]]'' reported that many people had judged the painting to be "over-valued."<ref name="LongFaces"/> Over the years, the painting has been owned by American art collectors Keith Warner, David Lloyd Kreeger and James W. Alsdorf.<ref name="ArtWolf"/>
In January 2011, it was announced that ''La Lecture'' would be included in an Impressionist and Modern art sale by [[Sotheby's]] in London on 8 February 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23917491-three-sothebys-art-auctions-expected-to-raise-pound-150m.do|title=Three Sotheby's art auctions expected to raise £150m|last=Blunden|first=Mark|date=26 January 2011|work=[[London Evening Standard]]|publisher=Evening Standard Ltd|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> The work was being sold by an American collector.<ref name="Bloomberg"/> Ahead of the auction, ''La Lecture'', which had not been seen in Europe since the Picasso retrospective, went on display in Paris.<ref name="Reuters"/> The painting was estimated to fetch between £12–18 million and Helena Newman from Sotheby's said that the painting will "excite a lot of interest."<ref name="Guardian"/> On 8 February, ''La Lecture'' was sold in six minutes to an anonymous telephone bidder for £25.2 million ($40.7 million).<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-12400465|title=Picasso painting La Lecture fetches £25m at auction|date=9 February 2011|work=[[BBC News]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Pablo Picasso}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lecture, La}} [[Category:Paintings by Pablo Picasso]] [[Category:1932 paintings]] [[Category:20th-century portraits]] [[Category:Books in art]]
